Is public transportation operating? â¯Yes    Masks must be worn while on public transport.    http://web.archive.org/web/20220724154409/https://bd.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
Only those who show symptoms of COVID-19 and subsequently test positive must quarantine.    http://web.archive.org/web/20220724154409/https://bd.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
Are there restrictions on intercity or interstate travel?  No    http://web.archive.org/web/20220724154409/https://bd.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Are health screening procedures in place at airports and other ports of entry?â¯Yes    Theâ¯GoBâ¯has begun distributing health information cards and conducting temperature screening of all passengers arriving in Bangladesh at all points of entry.    Is a negative COVID-19 test (PCR and/or serology) required for entry?â¯ Only for those not vaccinated in against COVID-19.    All those traveling to Bangladesh must complete a Passenger Health Declaration Form (HDF) within three (3) days of arrival in Bangladesh. The HDF will generate a QR code, which travelers must be ready to present to immigration authorities upon arrival at the port of entry.  Travelers who are fully vaccinated against COVID-19, regardless of port of entry, can enter Bangladesh with official proof of vaccination.  No PCR or any other negative COVID-19 test is required.  The government of Bangladesh defines fully vaccinated as having received a full regimen (one or two doses, as applicable) of a WHO-approved vaccine.â¯ At present, a booster dose is not required.  Travelers who are not fully vaccinated against COVID-19 must carry a negative COVID-19 RT PCR test report from a test taken within 72 hours of departure.  Children under age 12 are exempt from the testing and vaccination requirements but will observe the same health formalities that apply to their family members upon arrival.    http://web.archive.org/web/20220724154409/https://bd.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
No new announcements.  http://web.archive.org/web/20220724160325/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
No new announcements.  http://web.archive.org/web/20220724160325/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
COVID-19 Dynamic Dashboard for Bangladesh: https://web.archive.org/web/20220724161423/https://dghs-dashboard.com/pages/covid19.php

Theâ¯governmentâ¯of Bangladeshâ¯has provided a list of recommended COVID-19 testing facilities for international passengers. â¯Those wishing to get tested will have to pay for their own COVID-19 test.â¯â¯Results areâ¯oftenâ¯delivered via text message and are, in most cases,â¯linked to a QR code.  In Dhaka, it is relatively easy to secure test results within 24 hours, if not faster.  http://web.archive.org/web/20220724154409/https://bd.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
No change found.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220724162433/https://dghs-dashboard.com/pages/covid19-vaccination-update.php

As of July 23, 2020, theâ¯GoBâ¯will take legal action against those not wearing masks or social distancing. â¯Since May 30, 2020, theâ¯GoBâ¯has made wearing masks and social distancing mandatory when outside the home. Public administrators in Khulna Division have instituted a fine of TK 4,000 for those not adhering to this order.    http://web.archive.org/web/20220724154409/https://bd.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

There are no restrictions on movements within Nepal with a vaccination certificate. Local and private transportation are available. Public transport and personal vehicles, including taxis, are permitted in the Kathmandu valley and must adhere to COVID protocols.  Violations of local orders may result in penalties. Long distance buses may be operating in some areas of the country. Additional restrictions remain possible in many locations.   https://web.archive.org/web/20220606211735/https://np.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220307201443/http://www.xinhuanet.com/asiapacific/20220305/c56196aabeb8455abff9a196d31a61d3/c.html

Vaccinated visitors must present a certificate showing a negative RT-PCR test, taken within 72 hours of flight of first departure.  Unvaccinated people, or those unable to show that they have been fully vaccinated for at least fourteen days, are subject to free antigen tests on arrival. Although poorly enforced, mask compulsory everywhere outside. The government of Nepal has announced that failure to wear a mask outdoors may result in arrest and a fine.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220606211735/https://np.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220606211639/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/nepal/entry-requirements

According to MoH Nepal, as of late June 2022, 78.3% of the population have received the 1st dose and 69.5% are fully vaccinated. About 1 out of 7 Nepalese, 14% of the population has received a booster, after six months of booster campaign.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220523165444/https://covid19.who.int/region/searo/country/np/    According to covid-19 vaccine tracker Nepal has adminstered 9 vaccines (Moderna's Spikevax, Pfizer/BioNTech Comirnaty, Gamaleya's Sputnik V, Janssen's Ad26.COV2.S, Oxford/AstraZeneca's Vaxzevria, Serum's Covishield, Bharat Biotech's Covaxin, Sinopharm's Covilo and CoronaVac).  See link below:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220523164846/https://covid19.trackvaccines.org/country/nepal/    Government began administering booster dose of COVID-19 vaccine for people over 60:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220117204601/https://www.reuters.com/world/asia-pacific/nepal-starts-giving-covid-19-vaccine-booster-shots-2022-01-17/    Government began massively administering booster dose of COVID-19 vaccine for children 5-12 on June 23th:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220627191919/https://myrepublica.nagariknetwork.com/news/covid-19-vaccine-to-be-administered-to-children-in-the-5-12-age-group-from-today/    US donates 2.2 million doses of Pediatric COVID-19 vaccines to Nepal:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220620223334/https://thehimalayantimes.com/kathmandu/us-donates-22-million-doses-of-pediatric-covid-19-vaccines-to-nepal

According to MoH Nepal, as of early July 2022, 80.1% of the population have received the 1st dose and 69.9% are fully vaccinated. About 1 out of 7 Nepalese, 14% of the population has received a booster, after six months of booster campaign.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220523165444/https://covid19.who.int/region/searo/country/np/    According to covid-19 vaccine tracker Nepal has adminstered 9 vaccines (Moderna's Spikevax, Pfizer/BioNTech Comirnaty, Gamaleya's Sputnik V, Janssen's Ad26.COV2.S, Oxford/AstraZeneca's Vaxzevria, Serum's Covishield, Bharat Biotech's Covaxin, Sinopharm's Covilo and CoronaVac).  See link below:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220523164846/https://covid19.trackvaccines.org/country/nepal/    Government began administering booster dose of COVID-19 vaccine for people over 60:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220117204601/https://www.reuters.com/world/asia-pacific/nepal-starts-giving-covid-19-vaccine-booster-shots-2022-01-17/    Government began massively administering booster dose of COVID-19 vaccine for children 5-12 on June 23th:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220627191919/https://myrepublica.nagariknetwork.com/news/covid-19-vaccine-to-be-administered-to-children-in-the-5-12-age-group-from-today/    US donates 2.2 million doses of Pediatric COVID-19 vaccines to Nepal:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220620223334/https://thehimalayantimes.com/kathmandu/us-donates-22-million-doses-of-pediatric-covid-19-vaccines-to-nepal
